editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Covent garden: a pleasant comedy: acted in the year, mdcxxxii. By the Queen's majesty's servants.
London, printed by Richard Oulton, for Charles green; and are to be sold at the sign of the white lion, in Paul's churchyard. 1638.

div.head: To the right worthy of his honour's sr. John Suckling knight.
div.p: There is no excuse for this my presumption, but a presumption upon your 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉

It is likewise an error in my weakness, to put so mean a piece to a second trial; when in your perusal it will meet with a more piercing judgement, than the stages, that gave it some partial allowance. For the style, 'tis humble:Serpit humi tutus nimium, timidusque procellae.

Your own is Pindarus, mine Bacchylides. Yet I would have endeavoured to make the persons speak better, had it been proper to their condition. As you are a patron to all good endeavours, you merit to be the subject of many encomiums: but yourself by yourself in making the world (Which can never be sufficiently grateful for it) happy in the publication of your late worthy labour, have prevented the intentions of many to dignify that in you which is so far above them. My hope is, that by your favourable acceptance of this, I may gain some opinion with others; to whom I have and always do declare myself in my desires ambitious to be known by you at the becoming distance of

closer.signed: Your honourer and humble servant Thomas Nabbes.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: Do not expect th' abuses of a place;
Nor th'ills sprung from a strumpet's painted face
To be expressed. Our author doth not mean
With such vile stuff to clothe his modest scene.
Nor doth he brand it with a satyr's mark;
But makes a justice wiser than his clerk.
His rustics likewise will pretend to wit:
So all the persons which we counterfeit.
He justifies that 'tis no borrowed strain,
From the invention of another's brain.
Nor did he steal the fancy. 'tis the same
He first intended by the proper name.
'Twas not a toil of years: few weeks brought forth
This rugged issue, might have been more worth
If he had licked it more. Nor doth he raise
From th' imitation of authentic plays
Matter or words to height: nor bundle up
Conceits at taverns where the wits do sup.
His muse is solitary, and alone
Doth practise her low speculation.
He hath no faction in a partial way,
Prepared to cry it up, and boast the play,
Swelling your expectations: he relies
Merely upon your ingenuities.
The matter's weak: how can the building stand?
Yes; if supported by a gracious hand.

list.item: Jeffrey jerker. A lad of the same humour.
Dorothy worthy. Daughter to sir Gene.
Susan. A waiting-woman to the lady.
Spruce. Gentleman usher to the lady.

div.head: Act. 1. Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter dungworth, Ralph, and Dobson, as newly come to town by the right Scene.

sp.speaker: Dobson.
sp.p: _ now we are come to London, fellow Ralph what shall we do? or what course will our master take with us?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Why, Dobson; he may do what he will, and we will do what we list. A little instruction and practice will make us wicked enough, I dare warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: I hope we are not to learn that. But all this while the plough stands still.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Sha', Dobson; thy mind's upon nothing but dirt.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Indeed here's store of it, ankle deep.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: What place is this Ralph? thou knowest London.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: It should be Covent-garden; but 'tis much altered since I was here last.

sp.speaker: Dungw.
sp.p: A garden call you it! 'tis a very barren one.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: I would I were at home again, amongst the cream-bowls.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I could be content to have the tother smack at our Gillian the dairmaid's sugar-candy —

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: How, fellow Ralph! you kiss my sweetheart Gillian! pronounce it again, and by the faith of a new made servingman, that puts his whole trust in his livery and the quarter-days, I will kill thee presently, and challenge thee the next holiday before the congregation.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Kill me first, and then challenge me! for a kiss or two! nay, good Dobson; she has lips big enough to serve us both. Prithee let's not fall out and beat one another: these people would but laugh at us for't.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis a jolly company. Dwell they all hereabouts ?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I scarce think they are all of one parish, neither do they go to one church. They come only for an evening recreation to see Covent-garden.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Blessings on their hearts for it. 'tis a goodly place.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: And a godly one too if rumour lie not.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: What are all these things with rails?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I think mews for hawks, or ayrings for gentles. Other hawks are not here in any request.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: Mews for hawks, thou wouldst make me a buzzard.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Dost think we shall dwell hereabouts?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I hope so: we shall then be near the cock-pit, and see a play now and then.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: But tell me Ralph, are those players the ragged fellows that were at our house last Christmas, that borrowed the red blanket off my bed to make their major a gown; and had the great potlid for Guy of Warwick's buckler?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p:
No, Dobson; they are men of credit, whose actions are beheld by every one, and allowed for the most part with commendations. They make no yearly progress with the anatomy of a sumpter-horse, laden with the sweepings of Long-lane in a dead vacation, and purchased
at the exchange of their own whole wardrobes. They buy not their ordinary for the copy of a prologue; nor insinuate themselves into the acquaintance of an admiring ningle, who for his free coming in, is at the expense of a tavern supper, and rinses their bawling throats with canary.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: But I would I had stayed still in the country, now sports are tolerated, in despite of justice, Troublesome's malicious authority. I had rather see a morris-dance and a maypole, than ten plays: what care I for wit which I understand not?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: The duller ass thou.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: How, ass to my face! provoke me no more with such foul language, lest I enter and act thy tragedy.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Nay, prithee fellow Dobson; if we abuse ourselves sometimes, 'twill be the better taken when we abuse others.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: Tomorrow I'll have you accoutred in liveries, and put myself into a gentile garb. I am resolved to forsake the country profession of mine ancestors; and mean to turn gallant. I'll sell some few dirty acres, and buy a knighthood: I'll translate my farm of dirtall into the manor of no-place. Would I were acquainted with an honest scrivener.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: You wish an impossibility, unless the pillory were more terrible.

sp.speaker: Dobson.
sp.p: But do you mean to sell your land?

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: Yes indeed; I shall be the likelier to go to heaven when I forsake earth.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: But 'tis a dangerous way through a scrivener's conscience.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: What dost tell me of danger! 'tis the coward's bugbear; a scarecrow to city gulls, that dare not wear swords for fear of being challenged.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Nay, my master is as tall a man of his inches.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p:
Yes, Dobson; thou hast seen me do something.
But sirrah, let it be your charge to find out a good inn; see crop eat his meat.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: I'll warrant sir, he'll cat his meat, and 'twere Good-friday.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Had he but cares then, he might make a very good Puritan horse.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: Indeed, their best virtue is to hear well.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: But their doing sometimes, begets a hotter zeal in the sisterhood.

sp.speaker: Dungw.
sp.p: I'll have a lodging here. Prithee ask that gentlewoman; she seems an inhabitant.

div.head: The second scene.
div.stage: Enter Mris. Tongall, by the right Scene.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Pray master, know you hereabouts any convenient lodgings?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Many sir, for convenient persons.

sp.speaker: Dungw.
sp.p: Of credit, and unsuspicious.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: It is not in my understanding; wherefore the satisfaction I can give you will be doubtful. I know none of my neighbours better than myself. I have as handsome lodgings as any are in covent garden: my fore-rooms have a fair prospect, and my back-rooms a sweet air.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Which is not usual backwards.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: May we see them?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: If you please to let that tavern receive you till I have made them ready, I will return and give you notice.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: I'll sup there: shall I entreat your company?

sp.speaker: Tong ▪
sp.p: I shall be ready to fulfil your desires.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: And we our bellies: hitherto, we have had but a hungry journey of it.

div.stage: Dungwell and Dobson go forth by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: My friend, pray what's your master's name?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What if it be not in my commission to tell you?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: My demands are civil and for no hurt. I must know before my house can give him entertainment.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: But I must not tell you, till I have a mind to it. You may be the agent to an informer: do you not correspond with the summer and apparitor, to keep yourself off some deserved punishment.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: I am a patient bearer.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Not unlikely, I have heard there are many such in Covent-garden.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: I mean with your unmannerliness.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: If a downright ▪ country thing will please you.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: A downright! you make me blush.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: This interest then, and —

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: So sir, the terms are not equal for such familiarity.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Why then you must seek you a more proportioned schoolmaster to enter you farther, and teach you my master's name. The wine stays, and I want it.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Good friend stay a little, and tell me thy master's name.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What again! Fare you well, I have forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Nay, prithee friend: my knowledge of it may much concern his, or (If not) thy good. My daughter jinny a handsome girl, he that pleaseth me best shall have her.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I rather think he shall have her that pleaseth her best, else I shall doubt her for a woman. But how can she concern our goods? your instance.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Nay, credit me upon my word, 'tis earnest.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: A woman's word! 'tis not worth an ounce of feathers. Besides, you may be under covert barn. Have you not a husband?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Yes indeed.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What's his profession?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: An under-lawyer, an attorney.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: His word may be taken in the term for a gown-facing or so: but to do any man good, is worth a double fee, if he perform it. Mistress, if you must know my master's name, go to Carterton in the county of Sussex, and there in the church-register you shall find, that Roger the son of Rowland Dungworth of Dirtall farm in the parish of Carterton aforesaid, was baptised — but stay, I'll know first if he be resolved to continue a christian; 'tis ordinary to change names with religion. Besides, he means to be a knight; and Dungworth will stink in the delicate nostrils of a lady: it may make the heralds give him a mock-coat with three kennell-rakers. Farewell sweet mistress, and if my master chance to lie at your house, I should be glad if I might lie over your daughter.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Farewell good friend. The gentleman to lie at my house! very good. I must project a profit out of the accident; a new gown, or a beaver, or some composition with a bond of assurance, when I procure him a good wife. Perhaps he shall have my daughter Jynny. Who would think this little body of mine were so busy in stirring actions, master Theodore artlove!

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: Enter artlove by the right Scene.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: Mistress Tongall, you are delighting yourself with these new erections.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Fair erections are pleasing things.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: Indeed they are fair ones, and their uniformity adds much to their beauty.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p:
How like you the balconies? They set off a lady's person well, when she presents herself to the view
of gazing passengers. Artificial fucations are not discerned at distance.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: Pray which is sir generous Worthie's house?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Your desires (I believe) are bent towards his fair daughter. Let me aid you: my neighbourhood hath interested me in her acquaintance; I can make way; and truly Mr. Artlove I like you so well, that (Were she worthy) you should have my daughter Jinny. But do you love mistress Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: I have seen her beauty, and her nimble eyes
Have shot a fire into me, that inflames
My cold desires. I that have resisted
Th' assaults of passion to a perfect conquest;
And called it (Justly too) the height of folly
To give that wanton power the attribute
Of a false deity: ay, that have outgone
Th' example of Zenocrates, am captived;
But by a beauty, such as would review
Heat in the frozen bosom of an anchorite,
Who hath spent his age even to decrepitness
In such austerities as would mortify
The strongest pampered wantonness. I covet
A good success, but fail in't. Never yet
Could I be blessed with opportunity
To show her my desires, and to try
The fortune of persuasion.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: And would you not use me! hath so long practise in matchmaking made me politic to contrive, and my conversation with yourself and the rest of the wits made me complemental, and do you think I cannot facilitate your entrance to mistress Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Should I be fortunate in my attempts
To win her liking; should my person please her,
Or that annexion to my better part
Of education, yet the disparity
Betwixt our states, cheques me from hoping
that the design can prosper. The lighter fire
Ne'er mixeth with the earth, but to confusion: or from their several natures bringing forth events prodigious.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Why, you are an heir to a thousand pound a year. An officious lie may be dispensed with.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: But simple honesty
Clad in the naked livery of truth
Is a most glorious virtue, that preserves
White innocence unstained with falsehood.
Good means as well as good intention
Must make an act good.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: If you have such a tender conscience, so religiously scrupulous, you'll never be a politician.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Let those that study mischief
To satisfy their sensualities
Practise such wickedness. I'd not abuse
A noble goodness to possess the Indies.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: But here's one will, and I must aid him in't ▪ Mr. Littleword.

div.head: The fourth scene.
div.stage: Enter littleword, Jerker and Jeffery, by the right Scene.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Friend Artlove, the good fortune of a petticoat light upon thee, in the name of venery what mak'st thou here? art 'In quest of a smock-bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: Thy old humour still friend.

sp.speaker: Ierker.
sp.p: Prithee salute this little gentleman my cousin: he hath more age and wit then his small proportion doth promise.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: I shall be ready to serve him.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Your acquaintance will add much to my happiness.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: He hath gotten leave of his uncle to live here in my tuition. He thrives well in his conceit, a right jerker; he begins to love a wench already.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Thy instruction and example will soon enable him that way.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Is not that a wench cousin?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Try Cos. and satisfy yourself.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: My Littleword, if your salute be ended, pray resign. Nay, mistress, I can kiss you without the help of a joined stool: please you to walk, and let my hand support you.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Whither pray you little sir?

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: To the next vaulting school.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Alas, you cannot get up without a stirrup.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Yes, and ride too without falling; please you to try my activeness.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Prithee recall thy wonted goodness home,
And with a virtuous scorn shake off this habit
Of loose desires; it hath infection in it.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Nothing comes from thee but documents. I swear I should love thee much better if thou hadst less virtue. I prithee leave thy stoicism, and become an epicure with me. My little Cos. here shall prove with undeniable arguments that drinking and wenching are the only virtues in a gentleman of the last edition: to be excellent at them is a masterpiece of education. Besides, they are the only acumens of wit.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: Yes, to disease it.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Take heed thy judgement be not brought in question. Why diseased wits are —

sp.speaker: Ieffr.
sp.p: Better play at small game then sit out. A young gamester may throw in and in.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Very seldom with three dice. Can your littleness cog?

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Fair play is a gamester's glory. I love to shake the box well, and than let them run their length.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Yes, I confess it; where there is an union
Of loving hearts, the joy exceeds expression.
That love is virtuous whose desires do never
End in their satisfaction, but increase
Towards the object. When a beauteous frame
Garnished with all the lustre of perfection
Invite's the eye, and tells the searching thoughts
It holds a richer mind, with which my soul
Would rather mix her faculties.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Judge not of a man by his outward dimensions: my shape is not so defective to make you doubt performance: let's find out a convenient place and try.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Alas little one, you'll lose yourself: you'll never hit the way home.

sp.speaker: Ierker.
sp.l: 'Tis a bliss above the feigned Elysium
To clasp a dainty waste; to kiss a lip
Melts into nectar; to behold an eye
Shoot amorous fires, that would warm cold statues
Into a life and motion; play with hair
Brighter than that was stellified.
And when the wanton appetite is cloyed
With thousand satisfactions of this kind,
Then follow's th' absoluteness
Of all delight. But were desire restrained
From variation, soon 'twould satiate,
And glut itself to loathing.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Please you to drink a pint or two of wine? there may be provocation in it.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Preserve your courtesy child, and your money: lent's at hand, and then every street will afford boys recreation.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Why how now impudence! do you flout a man?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: How, a man cousin!

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: I want not so much of my full age to be called a boy.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: But you must not fall out with the gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: I desire rather to have fallen in with her.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: I would not have you so forward cousin. You must be sure to deal with sound ware.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: What care I? 'tis but the loss of a man's hair; an excremental ornament: wit consists not in't. A man may cover his baldness with a periwig, and the fashion takes away the suspicion. I hope I came to London to learn wit and the fashion.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Come Mr. Littleword.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: Adieu mistress Tongall.

div.stage: Exeunt Tongall and littleword, by the right Scene.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: I took her rather for a wagtail.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: What silent gentleman's that?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: His character in his own language is ay and no; yet he speaks well in paper. He is a wit, but somewhat a dull one.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: What serious affair have they together?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: There are hidden policies in the world. Thou hast a bookish humour; I a wenching one; and why may not his dulness dream of some rich match! mrs. Tongal's the only matchmaker in the town.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Those words create a hell of torment in me.
Is there no love
But what's attended by vain jealousy!

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Art thou in love?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Yes, passionately.
My dreamings, wakings, thoughts and actions
Are nothing but desire.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: I can as soon credit an impossibility. Thou in love! why 'tis more improbable than the projection of draining marshland with a windmill. But prithee what is she?

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: Enter Dorothy Susan in the balcone.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: See where my comforts sun
Breaks through a cloud. O that this unkind distance
Might be contracted into lesser air:
I'd then convey my whispers to her ears;
And teach her understanding what delight
Society hath in it.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Sure thou hast not boldness enough to speak to her. Thou wouldst blush, and fall into some pathetical book discourse, or tell her the story of hero and Leander, to make her tenderness whine. 'tis not the way. Get access to her; and after one mannerly salute, double and treble thy kisses; tumble her a little, and if opportunity serve, offer the rest: magic hath not a philtre like it.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Is not that a house (Cousin) where the wenches are?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Yes, questionless.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: I mean in the sense of —

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: Yonder gentlemen observe us: let's be gone.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Not yet (Mistress Dorothy.) Now I have drunk a cup of sack, I must be in love with one of them, him that seems most worthy of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: You have fallen my glove.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: I'll fetch it.

div.stage: Exeunt from the balcone.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Blessed accident;
Why do you stop my haste? let me embrace it.
Thus with religious worship do I kiss
What your white hand hath hallowed. Ha! she's gone ▪
What envious mischief intercepts the means
Of my desired happiness! or have mine eyes
Wasted their beams in gazing on the place
where I first saw her, to imagination
Fancying her figure.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Sure cousin the gentleman is in love; he talks very madly.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Where are the powers of my intellect?
Reason and understanding have forsaken
Their proper seats, and left strong passions
To triumph o'er this captived microcosm.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Now I see thou art mad: but prithee strive to conceal it; the place is public.

div.head: The sixth scene.
div.stage: Enter Susan by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Pray you sir, did you take up a gentleman's glove?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: It was my happiness, and 'twould be much increased, if I might kiss the hand that wore it.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman I shall be most careful to give your deservings their due commendations.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: May I be bold to enter with you?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You are a stranger sir, and it may give occasion of jealousy. But I am my lady's gentleman: I keep the key of her secrets, and if you please, her closet shall conceal you; where you may dispose of suckets and eringoes for your refreshment. I pray sir, call not a gentleman's freeness immodesty.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: My behaviour shall deserve your good opinion.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Truly sir, a man could not stand better in the conceit of a gentleman at first sight, than you do in mine. I hope your goodness will not misconstrue my readiness to humble my desires to your disposing.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: You teach me language which myself should use:
But if my gratitude doth seem to want
Verbal expression, I had rather act
than promise what I owe you.

sp.speaker: Leffr.
sp.p: This is pretty foolery, cousin.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Sir, you appear so replete with goodness, that I presume you cannot but answer the desires of a gentleman, who prostrates her love at the feet of your acceptance.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Doth she love me? what greater secret
Hath nature in her works then sympathy!
I do conceive a thousand fond expressions,
Which throng so fast, they choke the passage up,
That none can find an issue.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Out of fool's paradise: thou art in it. But pray you gentleman protract not his satisfaction with these circumstantial delays. Whilst mrs. Dorothy and he are busy, you and I will taste the sweetmeats in your ladies' closet.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: He means you should lie under him.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Fie little one, that you should so offend the chaste ears of a gentleman. But to you sir, the loadstone of my heart, that turns itself at your motions pointing still to the North of your love.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Indeed mistress 'tis a cold corner, pray turn it to the South, and let my needle run in your dial.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And since the ardour of my desires have urged my blushes to discover them; let not your appearing worth suffer such a disparagement to contemn a gentleman's willingness.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: How's this! why friend, did she not seem to come instructed (By direction) with an embassy as to prepare my love?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: No, no, she loves thee herself. Take her. Methinks she's very beautiful; what pinken-eyes; what a sharp chin! Why her features transcend Mopsa's in the Arcadia.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p:
Hath she not studied it cousin, think you? and
is transported to a humour of loving every man she sees.
I have known it in the country in an age-decayed waiting-woman.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: I cannot answer her; my heart is big with other thoughts; which till I am delivered of, I suffer torments.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Unfortunate gentleman as I am, to be thus rejected.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Will you resign your interest? I'll court her folly.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Take it,
But not t'abuse the others innocence.
Whilst I with sighs draw in th' unwilling air
Which she perfumed at distance.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Pray gentleman could you love me a little? I'm very sportive.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Truly young gentleman, I do not know what I may do when you come to your full growth.

sp.speaker: Iaffr.
sp.p: Blirt my lady's gentleman, who taught you to scoff at a man's person?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Cry ye mercy little sir; you may be the father of dwarves. The sack begins to leave working and by this time my lady expects her gentleman. Farewell, unkind sir.

div.stage: Goes forth by the middle scene.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Farewell loving gentleman. She hath prevented me. Sure friend she came but to mock thee. 'twas little less than downright impudence.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Let's to the tavern sir, and drown this passion in a cup of canary.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Come, come; I was ordained to do thee good. Thou knowest I had a mistress, whose friends disliking my wildness, married her to the father of the gentlewoman whom thou lovest (Horns be his punishment for it.) She loves me still; and I do not despair of making him cuckold. We'll arm ourselves with a quart or two, and then I'll bring thee to her.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Aid me love, wit and fate; that my desires
Burn not themselves without her equal fires.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: More passions yet! It thou the mark wouldst hit,
Let sack inspire thee: 'tis the soul of wit.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.l: Sack that makes prophets; gives a poet birth:
And then a wench; Elysium upon earth.

div.stage: Go forth by the left Scene.

div.head: Act. 2. Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Susan and Warrant, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Now I protest Mr. warrant, you wrong the love of a gentleman, in not imparting the cause of your discontent. Come not fees in roundly? Do not the delinquents understand, I'll speak a good word for you?

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: You are the only object of my thoughts. 'tis your beauty hath animated my presumptuous weakness to express how much my desires are yours.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Alas Mr. warrant how can a poor gentleman deserve it?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.p: Yes, you have power of my lady, and she much acquaintance at court. A pardon might be got.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: A pardon! bless me, for what?

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Not for murder; but for killing (Yet not a man) fairly in the field.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Are you earnest?

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: 'Tis not yet done; only I am resolved to do it, were I but sure of my pardon.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: If not a man, what then is it?

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: A mere superfluous compliment of state formality. One of my lady's raising. A fellow that hath cross capered himself out of a tailor into a gentleman usher.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Who Mr. spruce? but have you challenged him?

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Yes, with all 〈…〉 and circumstance. The weapon single rapier; the place the piazze; the time this moonshine night presently before supper.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And your quarrel my love. Well Mr. warrant; I know a gentleman hath interest in a lord at court, who hath long been inward with her. I'll warrant your pardon. But my lady expects me.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Dearest part of myself: to get my pardon, here's Spruce, now will I affront him.

div.head: The second scene.
div.stage: Enter spruce by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Spruce
sp.p: Our being my lady's gentleman usher, her 〈…〉 not protect you in the competition 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Warrant, 〈…〉 shred of baseness to 〈…〉 favours, and mine own deservings. Mr. S. secretary is my lady's gentlewoman, and 〈…〉 by privilege.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: By privilege spruce! Thou art a baboon of formality, and an ap● of court - ship. When I have killed thee, and get my pardon, I will have thy skin stuted; and with a protection show them at country fairs and markets for a Guinea pigmy.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Warrant, thou art the epitome of my master's authority, and the abridgement of his justiceship.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p:
Spruce, thou art a very louse, bred in thy cross-legged profession; that having sucked a little blood of gentility, instead of thy usual bread breakfast, art grown to a fancy familiarity, with thy maintainers. Thou buyest thy
laundry in Long-lane or Hounsditch with the impudence of a cheater.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Warrant, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: How ●lie. That somebody were here to stand betwixt us. Come not near me, lest I blast thee with the breath of my just indignation.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Keep at distance warrant, lest I tame thee, and send thee from constable to constable in a wheelbarrow.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: For this spruce I will not compassionate the good parts which my lady commends in thee. Thy fiddlestick shall not save thee; nor thy capering lift thee an inch from the ground which I have laid for thy destruction.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Warrant, thou art the very parings of a pedantic to flout the completeness of education. Because thy dulness is capable of no more than to frame Hetroclites from men's names, and scribble a warrant or a mittimus by a precedent; yet thou art a justice's clerk.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: And thou a lady's gentleman usher, a bundle of complemental follies stitched up with howdies. I will send thee anon upon a visit to the devil.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: Enter Susan, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Susan,
sp.p: Fie Mr. spruce and Mr. warrant, how loud you are ● my lady hears your noise, and is offended.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Yes, my rapier and mine arm shall maintain it upon his life, I love you best.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Indeed Mr. spruce and I love you.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: I'll maintain it against the life of all the world, I love you best.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Truly Mr. warrant and I love you.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: He that offers to love her besides myself, dies.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p:
Mr. spruce and Mr. warrant, send but for one
bottle of sack, and be friends; I'll love you both.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: I'll brook no rival.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Nor I; death must determine it.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Remember then, I must to the cutlers.

div.stage: Warrant goes forth by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Though I am but a waiting-woman, I have more wit than to believe this is earnest. As if I did not know them to be as arrant cowards, as a justice's clerk or gentleman usher can be; and deserve rather to be whipped by a satire, then rewarded for their valours with the love of a gentleman. But Mr. spruce do you mean to fight?

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Yes, and kill him too. I fear nothing but death and the gallows; from which you may save me.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: As how? the means.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Beg me, I say beg me. Let not my good parts be made unuseful by an untimely turn at Tyburn. Methinks I see the pitiful spectators condoling me. The fishwives drowning their dead soles with salt water from their eyes; the oyster-wives weeping for me in most lamentable pickle. An hundred chambermaids running stark mad, and as many more falling into the green sickness with longing for me. Beg me therefore (I say) resolve to beg me, and make great haste. It is my fear above death, that otherwise some rich city heir will prevent you. Resolve therefore to be the first that shall beg me.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman Mr. spruce, if you kill him fairly in a duel; and upon no base advantage I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Confirm it then with a kiss, and inspire an Herculean valour into me.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: By no means at this time. I'll kiss you at the gallows. My lady.

div.head: The fourth scene.
div.stage: Enter lady and Dorothy by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You see how my obedient youth
Hath joined itself with an unequal mate;
You aged father, only to satisfy
The provident will of parents. Do you so.
Fortune hath made me now your mother.
Had nature don't, my care could not be greater,
Nor more my providence to dispose your good.

sp.speaker: Doroth.
sp.l: Mother, the duty which I owe my father
You (Being his) must share: and this expression
Of more than common love, I must repay
With more than common gratitude.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: There. tell me,
Now time hath given your age perfection;
Your roses are full blown, and fit for gathering,
Do you not long for a husband?

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Not with much earnestness: I have as yet
No passionate desires; as yet no breath
Poisoned with hyperbolical flatteries
Hath courted my poor beauty; no deep vows
Have paid idolatrous sacrifice of service
To my fair hand, whose whiteness if but kissed
Can purify a soul. Believe me yet
The man's a stranger to my knowing memory
That ever said he loved me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But take heed:
There are a sort of fond effeminate men,
Deep studied in discursive compliment,
That many times will waste more airy language
To take a solemn leave, then would make up
A city orator.
Beware that no such oil-tongued amourist
sigh forth his passions in thy credulous ears,
And captivate thy weakness. 'tis their practice
To glory in diversity of mistresses:
And when one frowns or chides their overdaring
With a repulse, will not stick to revenge it
With a foul defamation of her honour.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Neither can a gentleman be in love now and then out she is censured.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Let not thine ears drink in their rhetoric charms,
Lest they bewitch thy glorious understanding
To dote on their pretences, which perhaps
Shall be chaste love for it's creation's end:
When but their covetous hopes prefer a portion
Before your beauty, birth or education;
And yet perhaps there is disparity
Betwixt lower fortunes, and their weak desert.
Deceit's a cunning bawd, and many times
Makes virtue prostitute itself to misery.

sp.speaker: Doroth.
sp.l: There is a power
Called fate, which doth necessitate the will,
And makes desire obedient to it's rule.
All the resisting faculties of reason,
Prevention, fear and jealousy are weak
To disannul what in it's firm decrees
Is once determined. Yet my heart is free;
Unbounded by the stricter limits of
Particular affection: so I'll keep it.
No proud ingrateful man shall ever triumph
O'er the captived sweets of my virgin love.
Nor a vainglorious gull that offers service
To every noted beauty, boast my favour.
I'll clothe my thoughts in humorous observation;
And if on any that solicits love
I fix a liking, I'll refer myself
To what is destined for me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The resolution's noble; I commend it.

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: Enter littleword and Mris. Tongall, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Welcome mistress Tongall; welcome. You are the only company in the neighbourhood. A lady can ill be without you.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: This gentleman madam, whom I presume to commend to your ladyship's acquaintance, is of worthy birth and education: the littlewords are not modern; besides their ancestors were great philosophers.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And the latter great fools.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Go, and talk to her. I'll tell your ladyship a strange thing of the littlewords. In seven generations there was but one girl, and she died an infant. Contrariwise of the Tongalls there's but one man left, that's my husband, and he's a lawyer: now your ladyship knows he gets nothing but wenches. Speak to her Mr. Littleword.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is the gentleman of so good education?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Extraordinary madam; he's a wit. I would my Jynny were worthy of him, he should seek no further. I pray Mr. Littleword speak to her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Can he poetize mrs. Tongall?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Excellently madam; he hath things in print. His next dedication shall be to your ladyship. Why do you not go and talk to her?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What estate hath he?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Five hundred a year present possession, more in reversion. This gentleman, mrs. Dorothy, is my friend, and desire's to be your servant. I have made way now, why do you not speak to her? I am bold to commend him to your liking.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Pray you mrs. Tongall, what wages takes he?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: You mistake mrs. Dorothy; 'tis your love he would serve you for.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: That's a cold reward; a livery would keep him warmer.

sp.speaker: Ton.
sp.p: Fie, that you will not speak to her. And how doth your ladyship like an old man?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A cold bed fellow. But religion and conscience. Now 'tis done I must love him. Would he were not jealous.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: None are so confident (Madam) as cuckolds. But your ladyship's known virtue will soon put out the eyes of his suspicion. Speak to her Mr. Littleword.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I would not now for all the sack in Spain my loving humour were upon me. This dumb gentleman would make me forswear the quality.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: Sure mrs. Tongall your friend would make an excellent midwife; he can keep secrets.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: 'Tis his modesty mrs. Dorothy. Bless me that you would not speak to her.

div.head: The sixth scene.
div.stage: Enter Jerker, Artlove and Jeffrey, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Madam, I am bold to commend this gentleman, who will deserve your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: As far as my power will extend to expression.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You are welcome Mr. jerker and this gentleman, and shall be whilst your visits are seasonable. But you know I have a jealous husband.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: There are medicines to cure it madam.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: May not I salute the lady cousin?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: 'Tis but courtesy and manners.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: I am bold with your ladyship's lip.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
'Tis marvel you blush not. So bold and so young!
By that time you come to your full growth pretty gentleman, you'll make up the number of the ten worthies.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Madam, I am neither infidel, Jew nor good christian; though I am little, I dare be your ladyship's champion in an active skirmish.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: This 'tis to be backward: you'll never thrive in any thing unless you are more forward. Lose such an opportunity with not speaking to her!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Secretary.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go, and direct the cook.

div.stage: Susan goes forth by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: How on a sudden my resolves are numbed,
And frozen into silence, that confirms
The first distrust of my known undeservings,
I dare not speak.

sp.speaker: Doroth.
sp.p: Shall I have another dumb servant! Are you not well sir?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Well lady! yes. Health itself
Is a disease in others, if compared
With th' absolute state of mine. Where you are present
Sickness can have no power over frailty.
The beames which your bright eyes shoot, purify
The most infectious air. Your words distil
A balm more precious than that miracle
The chemics dream of.
At distance I have often seen your beauty;
And thence received a fire, whose quickening flames
Did animate my soul, that else was earthy,
A lump of passive dulness; now 'tis active:
And if you please to cherish it, shall pay
All it's derivative abilities
Unto your lowest service.

sp.speaker: D●ro.
sp.l: You too much flatter my unworthiness:
And in that likewise derogate
From your own fullness of admired merit.
Th' unskilful'st physiognomist may read
In your bright forehead, and your form's exactness,
A man replete with all perfections.
Whose very superfluities might be
Additions to the barren worths of others.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: And can there be greater disparity?
Would it not seem a prodigy in nature,
To have green summer with her rose-crowned head
Kiss the white icicles from winter's beard?
Extinguish her bright fires in his cold bosom?
Madam, I know your sportive youth desires
A more proportioned mixture. Come, let's try.
Fire put to fire increaseth active flames;
Contraries dull each other with confusion:
Such are the frozen kisses of your husband,
Unto your warm delights —

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Lady, if any worth appear in me
It must derive it's fullness from your liking:
Had I infused into me all the excellence
Of those heroics whom the poets feigned;
Were I made up with all perfections
That fiction ever painted, to express
Desert in freshest colours;
Unless you called it worth, 'twere but a subject
For base contempt, though popular admiration
Gave't divine attributes. Since you commend
The faculties your whiteness must dispose of —

sp.speaker: Ieffr.
sp.p: Ask your husband leave! by this hand I would not ask an alderman leave to cuckold him. So he might take example from a city kind one, whose wife longed to kiss a lord: upon which he grew so proud for being exalted above the rest of his neighbours, that he would suffer none to cuckold him ever after but lords.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: By no means sir.
Wrong not your judgement, which must needs be absolute.
The choice of me
is too inferior to your richer value.
The Cyprian Queen had she but seen your face,
Would never have died the roses with her blood,
Wept on their paleness for Adonis' loss:
But circled in a ring of all her graces
Court your celestial form upon the bosom
Of some more fragrant Tempe.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: She mocks me sure.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Did Syrens hear your voice they would give o'er
Their own malicious charms: and through the witchcraft
Of it's more powerful music, rage with madness:
Leaving their proper element to die
In the pursuit of sweeter melody.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: This gross flattery, lady,
Commends your wit, rather than your good nature.
My heart is a plain heart, and my desires
Are truly virtuous, not to be contemned.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. jerker! besides the words incivility, I did not expect such absurdity in a reputed wit. Could you not have couched it better; shall I have leave to do your ladyship a piece of night service; or so. Come, come, forbear these wicked solicits, or I shall disclaim the promise of my favours reversion when my old husband dies, if nature be not merciless, and I go first.

div.head: The seventh scene.
div.stage: Enter sir generous worthy, and young worthy, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: Ha! what's here! Courtship on all hands?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My husband.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: My father, and my brother.

sp.speaker: Y. Worth.
sp.p: I like not this.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p:
Mr. jerker, you are welcome, I hope; having failed in his old, he hath not a new suit; that as I made
her a lady, she should bestow an honorable crest upon me.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Let his jealousy construe it into truth.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He shall never be but a unicorn.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Madam, however I appear in my wildness, I shall continue to your ladyship in my first desires. So with this tribute of my devotion.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: I would first kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: My lip being too unworthy.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: I take my leave madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Farewell mistress Tongall.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: Son, school your sister. Come with me wife.

div.stage: Ex.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: Sister, I can but wonder much, that you
Should make yourself the object of their courtship,
Who bear perhaps but th' empty names of gentlemen,
Without the real fullness.

sp.speaker: Doroth.
sp.l: What mean you (Brother) by this introduction?

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: Sister, to take the privilege of discretion,
And school your ignorant courtesy, that upon
The shadows and appearances of men
Confer your favours.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: Brother, you may pretend your love
In this distrust; but 'tis an ill expression.
Think not my judgement subject to such weakness,
That I can build a faith on compliments,
Or (With rash passion) run into an error.
Nothing but known desert shall tie my thoughts
To a stayed liking, if I may distinguish it.
And when my choice is fixed, it shall be such
As your fraternal love must not dispute.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: Sister, my counsel's mild.
Nor would I have you violent in defence
Of a suspected folly. Guilt is aptest
To make excuse. But if your resolution
Be bent thus wilfully to persist in actions
of feared dishonour, be assured my spirit
Shall rage with such an anger, plays never painted.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: Dishonour brother, I have a spirit too,
That scorns as much an act of foul dishonour,
As you, or any masculine pretender
To noble virtues. Guilt is aptest still
To be suspicious. If a maid be free
In her discourse, and courteous entertainment,
She straight is censured. But let a man appear
Stuck full of apish courtship; light, inconstant,
As talkative as parrots, that are taught
A voices imitation; one that courts
Every tamed beauty with a seeming zeal;
As if his soul's devotion were restrained
Only to her divinity; this man's called
A well-bred complemental gentleman.
Men's greatest follies, if compared with ours,
Are virtues, fit for our imitation.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: Sister, your satyr smarts not:
The lashes reach not me.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: They are but suppositions brother.
And pray suppose the gentleman that seemed
To court my beauty, were indeed a man,
Not guilded imperfections; one whose words
Were full of weighty judgement, not mere sound;
Whose real virtues did beget an envy,
Perhaps an emulation in all others;
And from the freedom of his richer mind
He gave himself and them to be my servants;
What gratitude in me might equal this?

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: I know you are free.
And rather than a complemental servant
Should be discouraged in his serious wantonness,
You'll give it countenance to make him bold
In's amorous pursuit; perhaps to th' impudence
Of a lascivious charge upon your modesty;
Because you scorn ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: Brother, did not the ties
Of love and nature check my forward aptness,
I'd tell you you're not noble, and suspect
Whether your mind hold that derivative goodness
Which generous blood communicates, to suspect
Her resolute constancy whom you call sister.
Think not your being a man prerogative
To be the only counsellor in manner's
Brother, though to your person I am partial.
Through confidence of your appearing virtue;
The general vices noted in your sex,
Such as with public ostentation
You glory to be guilty of, which in
Our very thoughts raise blushes —

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: Sister no more.
Leaving these circumstantial arguments,
Pray let a father's care and brother's love
Commend him first whom you intend for husband:
You'll find us tyrants else. Nature is kind;
But if provoked, she hath a tiger's mind.
I'll find him out and satisfy myself
How far he is deserving.

div.stage: Goes forth by the middle scene.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: How is our weakness trodden and insulted on
By these imperious men! Aid me resolves
Against their threats and counsels, unless grounded
On stronger reasons than suspicion.
As the pure oar refined exceeds in value
Treble proportions of the courser dross;
So true desert in man an outward gloss.

div.stage: Goes forth by the middle Scene.

div.head: Act. 3. Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Dorothy and Susan, in the balcone.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Come mrs. Dorothy; here's a moon would make a great bellied uman long for green chief. Methinks 'tis pleasant taking the air by moonshine.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: But 'tis not so healthful the night infects the air with unwholesome vapours.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: A fig for these physical observations. I have known a doctor's prescriptions cast down a gentleman for three quarters of a year. But if ever I lie under any of them for the green sickness.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: Fie upon thee.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Why I do not mean naughtiness. But what do you think made me so earnest to have you hither?

sp.speaker: Doroth.
sp.p: Some wanton humour. You have drunk a cup of sack, and want a handsome gentleman to be in love with.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: No such matter. I'll not drink a drop more till towards supper. I brought you to see a duel.

sp.speaker: Doroth.
sp.p: Bless me; betwixt whom?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: My lady's gentleman, and Mr. warrant.

sp.speaker: Doroth.
sp.p: They are unequally weaponed. Mr. spruce, though he be a tailor wears a — the foolish rhyme runs in my head. I had almost said a dagger, but 'tis a sword; and my father's clerk hath only his inkhorn.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And that's a terrible one. But I saw the cutler bring him a sword; I saw it naked, which was enough to fright many a gentleman. I saw him try it on a bar of iron in the kitchen; and many more fearful preparations.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: But will not you prevent them?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: By no means, unless there were more danger. 'twill be mirth for this twelvemonth, if our eyes (Through this imperfect moonlight) can but reach the sight of them. What confident daring will be betwixt them at some great distance?

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: And what's their quarrel?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: The love of a gentleman, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: Yourself perhaps.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: No otherwise indeed. My beauty is the object of their valour. The combatants will enter presently. The knight of the inkhorn, and the knight of the Spanish needle.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Both affecting the lady of the closet. But mrs. Secretary, what if my lady mother's chambermaid and Joan in the kitchen were here?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: For you to make them ladies, as you have done me. Indeed they might serve by moonlight; the day perhaps would discover a greasy gentry.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: Fie; now you forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: 'Tis ordinary for a waiting-gentleman but newly made a lady to forget herself. But see, I am prevented from proceeding. Let us observe.

div.head: The second scene.
div.stage: Enter Warrant, and a little after him spruce, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: 'Tis a good sword; it cost me two pieces. No matter. Many a man's death hath cost more at the physicians. Who would be afraid to kill a man; when he is sure of his pardon?

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: He is now in some deep meditation of your beauty.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: See mistress, there's the other.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: That sure is warrant. I'll go this way. It shall never be said I went after a man to kill him, though I am confident mistress secretary will beg me.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: They go contrary ways. We shall not see the fight. They mean to meet and end it at the antipodes.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: But what should I think of killing him? I know he dare as well take the wall of a drunken constable, or justle a buffcoat leading a wench, as meet me.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: methinks I perceive them stand.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Yes, yes; 'tis warrant: I smell him hitherto.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Is not that spruce? certainly 'tis he. Methinks I see him tremble hitherto. He dare not come near me; and I scorn to go to him to kill him: it may hinder my pardon. Therefore he shall assault me first.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: Why, they are fixed. Hath not fear congealed them into stones?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Dissolved them rather into jelly.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: That some good fellow would but come and beat the cowardly rascal.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: That some shark would come now and take away his hat or cloak.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Now could I fancy in my imagination what they say. Mr. warrant. O that I had this coward spruce here: I would dismember him; and then what gentleman would care a rush for him? Now Mr. Spruce hath studied the Arcadia. He says. O that I had this warrant here it would cut him into atoms; that wheresoever the sun shines, the trophies of my renowned victory might be visible.

sp.speaker: Aarr.
sp.p: That he would but come a little nearer.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: That he were but within twice my sword's length.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: I would I had but a leg or an arm of him, since he will not come, that I may kill him.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: That I had but his head here; how I would shave it.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: Enter Ralph and Dobson by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: This is the virtue of sack boy. Who would toil in dirt for whey and buttermilk, or the windy juice of pome-waters upon Sundays? Now could I be as valiant as — nothing.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: I could fight with an army of polecats, so they were not women.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I could take the wall of three times three tailors, though in the morning, and at a baker's stall.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: That were a way to have thy skin bodkin full of eyelet holes.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: If I should throw down three or four posts.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What then! why, I would not stay to take them up.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Who are these? observe.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Give me an armour of sack; I am shot-free.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Whilst my master pays the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Mistress Dorothy, I have fastened on a design for rare sport. My friends.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: Will you talk to strangers in the street?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What say you pretty pair of wagtails? do you want play-mates?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Will you do a courtesy for a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Within doors, or without?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You seem to be valiant.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: They that try us shall find our mettle.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Perceive you not two men yonder in several places?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: We see something, but they may as well be flocks.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p:
For any manhood that's in them. If you will but
beat them a little, besides a gentleman's thanks, some other reward shall attend it.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: How are we sure they are cowards?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You may trust the word of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Come, come, thou standest doubting like a cowardly fool, these may be gentlewomen of good fashion, and apt to take fire at valour. Who knows what preferment's near us? We have persons.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: Why then forwards: call upon sack, Dobson, sack.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Who are these come towards me? my courage begins to have an ague.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Who may these be? my wish (I hope) some good fellows to rob him.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: What was our commission Ralph? to beat them, and not kill them.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: To kill them and not hurt them? Call upon sack, Dobson: I begin to be afraid. I can perceive his sword; he shakes it fearfully.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Draw thine then; and sack, sack the walls of Troy.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: The rogue Spruce hath sent them to beat me. 'tis so. I must shift for myself.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Sirrah, thou man of fear and trembling. Call upon sack, Dobson.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Alas, what mean you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Not so gentle neither. We are fiery furious, and command thee in the name of sack, resign thy weapon, and submit to be corrected by our valour.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Kind gentlemen, I hope you'll not kill me. I'll do any thing, rather than be killed.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: A handsome beating shall assuage our fury.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Sweet gentlemen, I'll do any thing rather than be beaten.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: 'Tis so; they are robbing him, and I scorn to aid him. Teach the rogue to be such a coward: he might have come to me.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Are you prepared sir?

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Merciful gentlemen; I have some money, a cloak and a good beaver: I'll give you all, and forgive you too, so you'll not beat me.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: This was beyond our expectation.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Our mercy may be brought to a composition. But should we be pitiful, could you be content, since you cannot fight in your own defence, to lie in our defence.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: I'll say or swear any thing, rather than be killed or beaten.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: That we did beat you?

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: That you left me dead. I'll lie at a surgeon's these two months; and pretend that my skull was broken in twelve places: that half my brains were putrified and taken out. I'll be mad all my life after to confirm people in the belief of it.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Depart then, and praise us.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Yes, at the gallows. I'll have you hanged for robbing me: I shall teach you to attempt any thing on a justice's clerk.

div.stage: Goes forth by the right Scene.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Nay: pray you stay a little longer.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.p: I am weary; we'll imagine the rest done. I'll send my brother forth to make them friends.

div.stage: Exeunt from the balcone.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: 'Tis done sure. Now will I home, proclaim him a coward, and triumph. Ha do they waylay me! the rogue hath hired them to beat or rob me. An ague of fear is upon me. Now could I wish myself transformed into a beast, and have four legs. These two which have been my most useful members will surely fail.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Sirrah, you rascal.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: You mistake sir, I am a gentleman usher.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Then thou abuser of wit and good clothes, be mannerly, and uncover to thy betters.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: I hope gentlemen you do not mean to rob me? Trust me, I have no money, but a few farthings of my ladies to give poor people.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: We will be satisfied with a small diminution of your plentiful wardrobe. We know you have more cloaks and beavers at home.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: No I protest gentlemen. I have but this only case for my carcase: and 'twill not be quite paid for till the next quarter.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Why then sir, we will beat you handsomely, and that shall allay our fury.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Nay kind gentlemen, I had rather stand to my lady's bounty, then be beaten.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Why then thank our mercy and depart, whilst we like honest thieves share our booty.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: And I find out the constable.

div.stage: Goes forth by the right Scene.

div.head: The fourth scene.
div.stage: Enter Artlove by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: How glorious shows heaven with trembling lights
Sparkling their distant beams! The full orbed moon
Born on nights dewy wings, rides in her sphere;
And throws the shine which from her brother's rays.
She borrows to illuminate the earth
Through thinner air, where no condensed vapours
Are interposed to let her piercing eye
From seeing that which she gives sight to. Yet
My heart is wrapped in clouds of leaden sadness.
Love is not that in me which others feign it.
I dream not of delights; my busy fancy
Presents no fabulous heaven. A hell of torment
Darkens my mind's bright faculties; and reason suffers itself to be eclipsed by passion.

sp.speaker: Dobs
sp.p: Now w'ye are entered Ralph. what if we made this our profession? many a one lives by it.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: And many a one is hanged for it.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Oft have these instruments of heaven's influence
Seen my contemplative watchings;
When with profound and an unwearied search
I have scanned the causes of their great effects;
And waded through the most inscrutable secrets
Both of the mediate and immediate nature ▪
But coming once to read a woman's face,
There were so many heavens, that every thought
In me, required a several understanding,
To give each several grace a several name,
And definition.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Thou art afraid of the gallows?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Not much of the gallows without a hangman.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: The chaos and the earth were love's first parents;
And yet the child did give the parent's form.
What riddles are in nature!
Man's a disordered mass, a mere confusion
Of rude, inanimate sense and understanding.
Until inspired with love's diviner soul.
The sense is tired, unless it varies objects.
Knowledge would be finite, were not the mind
Delighted with diversity.
But love's a subject for eternal study;
And one fair book preserved so, a full library.

sp.speaker: Dobson.
sp.p: I am resolved; I'll nor spare man, woman nor child, whilst the sack works.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: For women and children let me alone: if I fall upon the one, I'll soon get the other.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: What fabulous errors learning is attended with!
Plato's five worlds; their sempiternity;
Pythagoras' transmigration; and opinions
Judgement would blush to father. But a woman,
Did men contemplate such a one as I do,
they'd make her all those worlds: and then include
All the famed excellence of former beauties
In her more perfect frame.

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: Enter young worthy by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: Is't possible such show of resolution
Should appear in cowards! I'll make them friends.
And that being done mine own intentions
Must be pursued to find that gentleman
Courted my sister. Love of all sorts bends
Itself to courses for it's several ends.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Now for a daring constable.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Without his staff of authority, or a fortification of sack. A constable may be valiant when he commands others what he cannot do himself.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.p: What! my pair of valiant cowards! friends already.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: How! Cowards! swallow that word, or it shall choke thee.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: These fellows have outgone their commission and robbed them. I was a wise man to come abroad without a sword.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: He hath never a sword. Sirrah, thou man of presumption, that hast profaned our incomparable valour, redeem thy forfeited life of our mercy with some gold or silver pictures out of thy silken pockets.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.p: They'll rob me too: why, gentlemen; silk clothes have not money in them at all times.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: He looks terribly Dobson. Call upon sack.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: I will cleave him at one stroke.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Do you mean to murder a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Murder a gentleman the voice came thence.
I'll rescue him, though danger and destruction
met me with open mouths. Villains, desist.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: You have done a benefit I must acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: That's to reward it sir; from which base ends
Good actions should be free. I'd gladly hear
A short relation of the accident.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Why dost thou quake so Ralph?

sp.speaker: Ralh.
sp.p: Why dost thou tremble so Dobson? I dare be whipped if these be not some kin to the gentle woman that sent us hither from the thing at yonder house.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Were you sent to rob or kill me?

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Alas gentlemen, we are very ingrams.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Mere country animals. We have valour to steal a maypole, or rob the parson's hens-nest: but to kill a man as far from our intents or daring, as pity from an executioner, or bashfulness from a Jingo.

sp.speaker: Y. worthy
sp.p: Forbear the rest. This affords me matter: return to that house, there leave your booty and receive your reward; only this I'll keep.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: With all our hearts: we had rather anybody should have them, than the hangman both them and us for them. Come Dobson, we have got the money yet; and a little sack will animate us again. My soul's under foot; I must raise it: but if ever I quarrel again by moonshine unless I am drunk, valour forsake me.

div.stage: Go forth by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: Blessed accident! 'tis surely the same.
After a stricter view, my memory
Unless it errs, tells me I have seen your person
Before this at my fathers.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: If you are the son of sir generous worthy.

sp.speaker: Y. H.
sp.l: It was the blessing
Nature and fortune did bestow on me.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: It is indeed a blessing, when the virtues
Of noble races are hereditary;
And do derive themselves from th' imitation
Of virtuous ancestors. You have a fair sister.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.p: Her beauty is not worth your commendations.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Your modesty is too severe
In your restraint from praising her pure excellence,
Which should be poet's study; not with fiction,
And common figures, but diviner attributes:
Then they must call it nothing but itself.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Have I found you? I shall search you deeper.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: The subject's weight would make a poem weighty;
And take away the imputation
Which seeming solidness would throw upon't
Of a light fancy.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: It seems you love my sister?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: He were a devil did not love such goodness.
It is the only virtue: frailty boasts of,
To love fair sensual objects: but my soul
Hath noted inward beauty in her mind,
Which makes me glory (Though it be presumption)
That I do love her.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: Cal't not presumption sir, you do deserve her,
In that you have endeared me for my life
Who am her brother. And I commend you wit,
Which I presume my sister's love hath whetted.
'Twas a quaint plot. Were th' actors here again,
I'd pay their wages.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: Your riddle needs some Oedipus to solve it.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: Why sir, ridiculous fables
May sometimes serve for imitation.
Though 'twere a mere appointment in this rescue,
To show your love and valour.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: What base suspicion
Poisons his jealous thoughts! 'tis injury
Beyond all patience.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Alas sir, you are moved?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Yes, to an indignation, whose just heat
Burns me almost to rage. But there are charms
and spells about you conjure down my spirit.
You are her brother.

sp.speaker: Young. Wor.
sp.p: It seems your guilt dare not deny the truth?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Dare not deny it!
Were thy hands armed with thunder;
Hadst thou a Gorgon's look, were't not her brother,
Ringed in the terror of a thousand gibbets
And executioners, I have a point
Should find thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: But I must tell you sir,
Seldom high spirits that pursue their honours,
With earnest flights, will stoop at weak respects:
But prey upon th' opinion of those men
That scan their actions; tearing their reputations
Out of suspicions bowels. He's not a gentle man
Will not preserve his honour.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Your speech, sir,
Savours of strange severity. My honour
Is that part of myself, without which
The man that's in me can have no subsisting.
Honour's the greatest of exterior goods,
And must be still pursued as the reward
Due unto virtue, through the greatest dangers.
Yet fortitude is not the appetite
Of formidable things, nor inconsult
Rashness; but virtue fighting for a truth;
Derived from knowledge of distinguishing
Good or bad causes. Think me not a coward
Because I am not rash: nor through defect
Of better counsel, do not resist the force
Of will or passion; howsoe'er your jealousy
Proceeding from our better thoughts infection
Hath been a provocation. And perhaps
The love I bear your sister, will appear
Your chiefest safety.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: In an attempt of right
I have more safety here then your presences
Can arm me with but if you love my sister,
It must be honourable and not wanton:
She will find champions ●eise.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: I must be honourable!
Those words include a doubt works strangely in me.
Love must not wrack my reputation.
Sir, I begin to scan the circumstance,
And construe your intention. You would try me:
But your temptations have been too abusive.
And now my resolution is prepared
To do my credit justice.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: You will not fight with me that am her brother?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: There's magic in those words.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: I do presume my sister will reward you
For these expressions. She is free to pay
Her servants promised wages; be it kisses,
Or any other dalliance.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: What a profane breath from his black mouth flies,
Would poison all the idolatrous religions
That e'er awed wicked mortals.
He is not sure her brother, but some impostor,
That only counterfeits his worthier person,
I could be patient at the lie, or coward,
Or any thing that can make passion violent.
But her bright honour stained's a cause of justice
To arm a nation. Draw, if thou'rt a man;
And with the plea of valour, (If thou'st any)
Defend thy errors: draw thy sword.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Not against him that loves my sister.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Is my just anger mocked! love made ridiculous!
Draw; lest I make myself an executioner.
And do an act of justice on thy guilt.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: Never against your bosom, where a spirit
So truly noble dwells, that hath converted
All my feigned jealousies to useful love.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: I am confounded to amazement.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: Pray reconcile all your distractions.
Let not the least distrust abuse your confidence
Of what I undertake. My sister's yours,
If the advice of me that am her brother,
And interested in her good or ill,
Can be prevailing.

sp.speaker: Artl
sp.l: Then requesting sir,
That you'll presume no more upon the privilege
Of that pure love I bear your virtuous sister
To admit a jealousy of any action,
Or thought of mine which tends not unto nobleness,
Next unto her my bosom holds you dear,
And shall do ever.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: So mine the like. Thus noble causes
Put fire into the spirits of full men.
Though sometimes seeming valour may arise
Through lust or wine, from hateful cowardice.

div.stage: Go forth by the left Scene.

div.head: Act. 4. Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Jerker and Jeffrey, with a drawer, by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon, anon sir, by and by.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Some more wine boy. Is Mr. art love returned?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not yet sir.

sp.speaker: Jeffrey.
sp.p: Poor gentleman; he's complaining to the moon, or studying the event of his love in the stars. Methinks I could make a counterfeit expression of his passions to the life.

sp.l: 〈…〉 ministress
〈…〉 light; dance 〈…〉 unequal motions
On thy four orbs; but quench thy paler fires
In lovers tears, that all in constancy
May so be drowned. I would I were in love cousin.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: Before you are capable of it.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.l: Why cousin, is it not defined to be youth's folly!
Indeed, all things in youth are folly.

sp.speaker: Ierk
sp.l: Not so coz. all folly may be in youth:
But many times 'tis mixed with grave discretion,
That tempers it to use; and makes it judgement
Equal if not exceeding that which palsies
Hath almost shaken into a disease.
But why would you be in love coz.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: That I might poetize: you know 'tis the only dancing master to teach the art of measures; though I have known poets scarce able to stand on their feet.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Then you would write satyr's coz?

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: 'Tis your dancing conceit. But the grincome's cousin cleaves not the feet.

div.stage: Enter Dasher.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Mr. Dasher, this freeness hath doubled the favour; visit us of your own accord!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Gentlemen myself, and all that depends on myself, or on any thing that hath dependence on myself, is at your service.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: I should desire your wife then.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sweet young gentleman, you are the epitome of a fair body, and shall command the commander of myself and family. I will but present a glass of Greek sack to the hands of a noble lord, and return to serve you.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: You have a virtue sir, I could wish communicated.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: What's that cousin?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: To cozen cousin.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: And would you learn it?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: The theory, but not the practice. I converse much in taverns; and the use should only be a thrifty prevention.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: As my observation hath taught me something in a bawdy house, where they cannot change money.

div.stage: Enter Dasher.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Now gentlemen dispose of your servant.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Indeed Mr. Dasher our wine's naught.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: How I naught I who drew it? name but your drawer; he is punished whilst you pronounce it. I'll not keep an offensive mouse that eats the crumbs under my table, but shall pay his life to do you service.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Why cousin, the wine's good.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: I only gave him matter for a compliment.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: 'Tis pity to abuse him that is so apt to abuse himself. But what do you muse on cousin?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: I am studying a conceited health.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Why to the long standing of Banbury maypole.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: No Puritan will pledge that.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Yes, the goodwives: they'll find dancing a more wholesome exercise for the body, than some of their doctrines for the soul.

div.head: The second scene.
div.stage: Enter art love and young worthy, by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Art come friend, and Mr. worthy?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Our mutual loves.

div.stage: Enter Dasher.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I am bound to serve you gentlemen, and I wish my roof were worthier, and my disordered household ordered to your content.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: We are bound to thank your readiness.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your servant will send his servants to wait upon you presently.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: What accident brought you two together?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: The mercy of my starts: but what event
Their influence will direct, I cannot prophesy.
Prithee be careful, he's a cynic noter
Of men and of their manners

sp.speaker: Ierk.
sp.l: If he bite.
Here's that shall blunt his fangs.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Good friend be mild;
Temper thy passions here. Scandal may grow
From low foundations to an height of infamy.
Thou knowest my temperance doth not oft frequent
These public places.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: Sir, the relation 'twixt a son and father
May make you jealous of my partial nature.
Trust me, I never yet was so indulgent
To mine own weakness, that until my judgement
Had made a full distinguishment of causes,
I could be violent in his defence
Farther than physical duty; which sometimes
Hath stretched itself to counsel and advice
Against suspicion. For though your wild behaviour
In some particular actions might provoke him,
She whom new duty makes me now call mother
Hath given large testimony of her virtue
Even to satisfaction of all goodness;
Although his age (In other things judicious)
Cannot so easily admit belief,
And safer confidence.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: Though I appear
In outward carriage apt to make distrust
Condemn me vicious; yet my soul retains
(Besides a generous disposition
Derived from noble blood) some scrupulous sparks
Of better conscience. Call it not self-flattery
in that I am mine own defences instrument.
Report sufficiently may inform your knowledge,
(Nor is it error) that my interest
In her you now call mother
Was beyond all dispute: our equal loves
