Moved in one circle; and our thoughts were fixed ▪
Nor can I vary; she's the object still
Of my desires. I confess I use
Wanton solicits; and should scarce resist
My wishes' satisfaction she consenting.
But those delights would end in such a loathing,
That I should never more have merciful thought
There can be any goodness left in woman.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: This jars upon my heartstrings.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: Dost distaste you sir,
That I defend myself?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: You must not wrong my father.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: I do abhor the thought of injury.
Nor shall my spirit fall in the just plea
Of mine own right.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: But not to wrong my father.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: If he be abusive, cousin challenge him. I'll be your second.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: He's not a crane coz.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Nor I a pigmy; you mock my love.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Your forwardness is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.l: Why, he can never have wit, that is not valiant.
I'll try him myself, if not to disturb you sir.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: I thank you little one.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: How little one I is not that an affront cousin?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: 'Tis as you take it coz.

sp.speaker: Artl
sp.p: Fill some wine boy: never a drawer here?

div.stage: Enter Dasher.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What gentlemen, none to attend you? (Whooh) an unlooked for happiness that my unworthy self is preferred.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: An inferior servant may serve, Mr. Dasher.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I am the servant of my servant that shall serve you. And unless he serve you he is not my servant. I'll turn them all away presently for this neglect of your worthy persons.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Men wear swords sir.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: And boys too sometimes.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: You'll answer it?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Answer what child?

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Little one! Boy! Child! I shall be degraded next to an infant.

sp.speaker: Ierker.
sp.p: Fie cousin, contain. The gentleman cannot brook it.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Yes sir, he can brook any thing but wronging of his father.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: I pray no more, the subject is too harsh
To make good music in society.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: Then here's a health to her that best deserves
The attribute of fair: whose white and red
Prove what's life's mixture. From whose forms exactness
Rules of proportion might be better drawn
Then from arts principles. To her whose youth
Warms winter's icy bosom with her spring;
Yet will not wrong your father. As it goes round,
Each give his mistress some commending character.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: Why then a health to her whose beauties are
Not a gross earth, with painted superficies;
But a more sprightly element of pure fire.
Within whose sphere a glorious m●nde doth move
All th' orbs of virtue with celestial flame.
Whose active climbings carry her desires
To th' utmost height of nobleness and honour:
To her that calls you brother.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Let not your love appear so full of flattery.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Nay, coz; 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.l: Then here's a health to her will freely put
her sweets to use. Kiss, and be kissed again
Without a fie. Whose boldness will not blush
At an assault, or any wanton touch.
And if a man persist to farther doing,
Accounts it loss of time, a tedious wooing.
To her that I call mistress.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Bravely come off sir.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: I can come on sir.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: Now sir, 'tis yours.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: This sack shall then have my encomium.
Which had the youthful father ever tasted
He would have left his rites to poetize;
And changed his ivy chaplets into bays:
Unchained his spotted linxes, and supplied
His chariots loftier course with Pegasus.
And with bewitching numbers charmed the gods
To be his bacchanalls, that they might feast
With this most heavenly nectar.

div.stage: Enter Dasher.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Mr. Dasher, your wine is highly commended.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I can assure you gentlemen, the grape from whence this sack was pressed —

sp.speaker: Young ▪ W.
sp.p: Grew in Spain.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I would have fetched it farther gentlemen to do you service. A voyage to the Indies should be no more than a descending into my cellar, and up again.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: You have handsomely contracted your journey.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: But Mr. Dasher, you have an eminent house, extraordinary wine and entertainment; but no sign at first to distinguish it.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: methinks cousin, the loggerheads was a pretty conceit.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: Had there not been a third.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Gentlemen; I intended a pair of scales with a glass of wine in one balance, and a piece of gold in the other, or a jewel.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.p: An excellent conceit, to show the value of good wine.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sweet gentlemen, I am the servant of your noble wits. I must kiss the fair hand of an honourable lord, who is now departing: I will then return to be disposed by you.

div.stage: Exit.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: Enter sir generous, young worthy by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.p: Sir 'tis my father.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: Ha! my son here, and Mr. jerker!
I came i'th' person of authority,
Invited by your noise. But that put off,
Out of my love born to the general good,
I do advise you to be temperate:
That the fair hopes conceived of growing virtues
Might not be lost. 'tis pity that your wits,
Which (Joined with some experience) might deserve
To fill the seats of magistracy, and be
A speaking law) should spend themselves in places
And acts of sin and shame; wherein severity
Of law and government must not be partial.
Therefore I pray no more of these disorders.

sp.speaker: Y. Wor.
sp.l: Pray sir, take nothing ill. 'tis the necessity
Of his place: his disposition else is milder.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: Sir, we are gentlemen; and by that privilege
Though we submit to politic government
In public things may be our own lawmakers
In moral life. If we offend the law
The law may punish us; which only strives
To take away excess, not the necessity
Or use of what's indifferent, and is made
Or good or bad by 'ts use. We do not drink
to a distemper, and from thence derive
Th' original of mischiefs: nor is pleasure
Our law but temperance. Creation made
Every thing good, if we abuse it not.
Then good sir, (Though you find enormities
Amongst the rabble) be not so suspicious
Of our more careful carriage, that are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: You have said to satisfaction
And more than I expected. Hark you son.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: I did not think thou'dst been so good an orator.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: Why friend? because wanton familiarity
Make's us less serious when we are alone,
Must it necessitate we cannot speak
In a high cause! Cousin, you must be careful
Of your behaviour: you are before a justice.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Why cousin, have justices power over a man's will?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: Some busy ones have arrogated much;
But being told their own have ever since
Given gentlemen a due respect.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.l: I'll make a trial here. Please you a little
To put off this severer gravity;
And drink a glass of sack. Your age is privilege
In what the law of moderation,
Denies our hotter blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: Pretty sweet gentleman. Is't possible
That one so young, should have so grey a wit;
'Tis wanting many times in graver beards.
Please you Mr. jerker, to bring these gentlemen to my house to supper. You'll find some empty dishes.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: We know your table's plentifully furnished.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: This was very good sack, neighbour. Pray send me home a dozen bottles. And keep good orders.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: The best orders that can be kept in my houses or any office of my house shall be at your worship's service.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Fogh; that compliment stinks.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: You are very courteous, neighbour. Will you go along with me gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: We are your servants. 'tis a blessed opportunity.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: You shall now make trial of my professed love.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: The reckoning m. Dasher

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: We'll take the Barr●●● our way.

div.stage: Go forth by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Dasher.
sp.p: You'll do me honour to pay it there. Ten thousand welcomes wait upon you gentlemen (Who) come sirrah, be the Mercury of neatness, and nimbly set this disordered room in order. Then give the gentleman below notice, that it is now ready to do him service: he's like to be a bountiful guest. He talks of selling his land, and being a wit: but how can that agree together I yes, very well. A country gentleman to sell his land, is as it were to change his copy: leave his known trade to project a better profit. Which changing of copy here with us, ends many times in the city freehold at Ludgate.

div.head: The fourth scene.
div.stage: Enter dung worth, Ralph and Dobson, by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Worthy sir, I have now made ready a room to entertain your worthy person. My house was so crammed with lords; and this especially with most choice gentlemen, some of the admired wits, to which very name I owe respect and service.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: 'Tis a fine chamber, it shines like a goldsmith's shop in Cheapside.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p:
'Twould much endear me to your kindness to bring me acquainted with some of those wits: you say they keep their rendezvous here many times. If I may
mould myself capable I should gladly add to their number. Indeed, I have had but country breeding.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: City bringing up forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Yes; for we rid like mad men.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Questionless, sir, there are of the wits some mercenary ones, whom your money may command to be your servants. But these are of a nobler strain. Howsoever, I will upon the next occasion show my desire to do you service.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Prithee Ralph, what be those wits? A family?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: No Dobson, they be of all tribes. Some are Jews, and some are gentiles. Some are noble both in blood and condition, and some in neither. Some study arts of use; some of delight; some conceive well, but talk wickedly.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Those be the women Ralph.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: No interruptions. Some break jests; some break pates; some break tailors; and some break their fasts with Duke Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: A wise housekeeper belike.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Some wear plush that others pay for. Some love sack, and some love wenches. Few will die of the alderman's gout, and some will never be cured of their own —

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: I understand thee Ralph. But how comest thou to know all this?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Tut man; I lived in London before now; was servant to one that conversed much with the wits, and kept an academy of music. I tell thee Dobson, I have picked up more learning among the crumbs of a broken biscuit, after one of their meetings at a tavern, then would make twenty ballad-makers commence poetasters; and with the overplus indoctrinate ten justices clerks, and an under-sheriff.

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: Enter Mris. Tongall, and littleword by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Dungw.
sp.p: Sweet mistress, you are welcome to my expectation.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: If my presumption to bring a worthy acquaintance along with me, seems not unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Dungw.
sp.p: You rather express kindness to a stranger that desires worthy company.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Dasher, you are the best woman vintner that ever loved a gossip's tale. You have so many good things to pleasure a woman with. You were wont to have an excellent neat tongue.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sweet mrs. Tongall, my best tongue, and all is at your service.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Kind master Dasher.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: To your welcome mistress.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: My humbleness receives your favour thankfully. My service to you Mr. Dasher.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I kiss the hand of your servant.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: And make a leg. This vintner sure hath had very mannerly breeding. he came not from the banks side, where the surly watermen live.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Noble sir, I presume to present my desires to do you service.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: This gentleman hath less manners. He answers nothing.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: My friend (Sir) though he be of few words, is a fine wit, and a great observer.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: A wit, mistress; I shall be the prouder of his acquaintance. But when I am a wit, I shall prefer my talking before my observation.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: I thank you Mr. Littleword.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Mr. Littleword and mrs. Tongall! very good. Sure this woman had a Frenchman to her father.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Indeed Mr. Dasher, 'tis excellent sack. If you were unmarried you should have my daughter Jinny, for keeping such good Wi●● in your house.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I retribute all due thanks for your kindness, that you would do me so great an honour.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Mistress, you said I should have your daughter.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: My friend, why so thou shalt. This sack makes my heart merry.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Who then shall my master have?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Why my daughter Linny.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: A right woman: so her tongue go, no matter what she says.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What will that gentleman with his table-book!

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: Let's have a health to somebody .

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Please you sir, to my daughter Jinny.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: Let it go round then.

sp.speaker: Tongall.
sp.p: And he that will not pledge it, shall not have her.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: I hope we shall drink now Ralph.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Else we lose both our share of the sack, and our hopes of her daughter Jinny.

div.stage: Ent. drawer.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: Some more wine.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: (Whooh) be nimble sirrah; and bring of my kingdom (That's my word for good wine) that it may wait on these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: William, thou art an honest fellow; and if thou bringst us good wine, thou shalt have my daughter Jinny from them all.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sure this gentleman writes what I speak. I hope 'twas not treason to say my kingdom. I would I knew what he were.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: The vintner seems troubled at this gentleman's table-book.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p:
'Tis his practice of observation. He is taking
a humour for a play: perhaps my talking of my daughter Jinny.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: I'll hatch some mirth from it. Sir, you must not take it ill, if I tell you of your errors. You have spoken something rashly.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Kind and worthy sir, my life is your servant for this noble care.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: That silent gentleman is an intelligencer; a state spy. He'll inform against you. Therefore comply with him to prevent it. 'tis his policy to say nothing himself, that his observation may be the more, and his own danger the less.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sir, I owe your goodness all that ever I have been, am, or shall be. He writes again.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: Now Mr. Littleword, you have some fine matter there to work upon.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To undo me. Sir, I desire you will command all that is to be commanded in my house to do you service. Yes, yes; he writes again.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: That word command is a word of great danger, I would you had not used it.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Alas sir, mrs. Tongall, 'twas not neighbourly done of you to bring an informer into my house.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: How, I bring an informer! as I am a matron, he's a gentleman, a wit, and a rare projector.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I believe it, to undo a poor vintner, that cannot compliment a gentleman into a ten pounds expense; but his neck must be in danger. Sir, if I were a King I would be your servant. He writes again.

div.stage: Enter a boy.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: Bless me sir, you have spoken treason.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Alas, sir, I, am undone then.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Master, the constable and other officers are coming up.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, yes; to apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: 'Tis for us, Dobson.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: The constable ▪ I hope we are not suspected persons.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: If I thought you were, you should never have my daughter Jinny.

div.head: The sixth scene.
div.stage: Enter constable and officers; by the left Scene.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: By your leave gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: You are welcome sir, and I pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: But not without you sir. You are suspected, and must answer —

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: Answer what? here are neither traitors nor felons.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I fear I shall be proved both.

sp.speaker: Tong ▪
sp.p: No sir, nor night-walkers that are taken up, and cast down I have declared myself of as good carriage as any in the neighbourhood; and my daughter Jinny waits upon an honourable lady.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Mr. Constable, I am your servant, I hope you suspect no traitors in my house. If you do, they shall wait upon you into the cellar; and there commit what treason you will against as good sack as is in the King of Spain's dominions. The gentleman writes still. I am utterly lost.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: There are two suspected to be here, that have broken the peace, and committed a robbery.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Deny it Ralph.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I tell you constable, there are none here, but can break the peace, as well as you that are a constable.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: They shall obey your authority, and in the vintner's phrase wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I fear I must wait upon the gallows.

sp.speaker: Dungw.
sp.p: Being my servants, I'll go likewise along with you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, yes; a mere plot to go along, that he may witness against me.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Fear nothing Ralph, the gentlewomen will not see us hanged.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: But they may suffer us, and that's a word for hanging.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: You seem apprehensive of your own danger. There's a reckoning to pay; if you but forgive it, I'll free you from this gentleman's information.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Most gladly sir, and be your servant. But how shall I be sure of it?

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: You shall hear it from his own mouth. You will not (Sir) inform any thing against this man! I pray say no.

sp.speaker: Little.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I am satisfied: and will be your servant in any thing but treason.

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: But be sure you speak to mistress Dorothy. Nay I'll along with you too, and perhaps speak a good word.
I have acquaintance with the justice, and his clerk knows my daughter Jinny.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Let me be your servant Mr. Constable, and light you down. I hope my house will receive no scandal by this.

sp.speaker: Dung.
sp.p: 'Twas a beginning yet, and more may hit.
Thus in th' abused sense cheating is called wit.

div.stage: Go forth by the left Scene.

div.head: Act. 5. Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Susan, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Thanks honest Nicholas. 'tis time to cover: my lady will to supper so soon as my master comes home. He brings strangers with him. This butler is the kindest fellow to a gentleman; and deserves my love more for this bottle of sack, then warrant or spruce for fighting. Come thou inspirer of a diviner soul, that teachest mysteries, of which without thee none are capable: to be valiant; to love; to poetize: suffer a thirsty gentleman to delight her dry palate with thy sweet moisture, and refresh her spirits with thy comfortable operation. (Drinks) excellent sack, as I am a gentleman. Now am I in love with my old master for buying it; with the vintner for selling it; with the drawer for drawing it; nay, with the very porter that brought it home: but most of all with kind Nicholas for bestowing it upon me; good heart, he hath ventured a chiding if it should be missed. (Drinks.) What foolish poets were they that made the more foolish gods drink nectar! Had Apollo presented Daphne but with a cup of such sack, she would have loved him, as I do Nicholas: but not to lie with him. A gentleman must not humble herself to a butler. (Drinks.) My lady.

div.head: The second scene
div.stage: Enter lady, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Lady ▪
sp.l: What is't should make my husband's jealousy
Rage ●o within him to suspect the visits
Of every friend! Cannot my careful carriage
Kill his distrust, and make him confident!
Many a young lady that had such excuses
As I may well pretend, his age, diseases,
And all the cold defects are incident
To a decaying strength, would privilege
Her rasher wills dispense with young desires.
Such are in me; but not to satisfaction:
I must not wrong my fame: though my hot blood
Should dance a lustful measure. But he's jealous;
And I must practise some strange cure upon it.
Secretary.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why do you gaze upon me?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I would not for th'exchange your ladyship were a man.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And why so?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I should run mad, for love of your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What humour have you got? you have sure been tippling. Fie secretary.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I hope your ladyship hath a better opinion of your uman, then to be earnest because she jests.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You know Mr. jerker?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: A very handsome gentleman. I wonder no worthy gentleman is in love with him:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No secretary; what think you of me?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Doth your 〈…〉 truly and so do.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But not as I do ▪
I could betray mine honour to his love;
And sell my fame for his 〈…〉 embraces ▪
Give those delights which are my husband's due
To his enjoying.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: And will your ladyship discover this to me? Truly I mean not to be degraded from your ladyship's uman, to hold the door, and cry, my master's coming.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Thy employment shall be
Whe● we are closely set at dalliance
Blush not whate'er thou seest; but call thy master;
The service may be worth a new gown.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: How, call my master! Did ever any lady enjoy a friend in a corner, and wish her husband (Who is sufficiently jealous already) to see it! Now as I am a gentleman, and had rather be a lady, 'tis not my mind.

sp.speaker: Lady ▪
sp.l: But 'tis mine;
His knowledge of't would add to the delight,
And make th' offence less. City dames can practise
Slights to deceive their husbands, mine shall know it.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: But is your ladyship earnest?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: As earnest as resolves can make me.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: But I am resolved not to obey your ladyship. Shall I that am my lady's secretary as it were, be treacherous to her secrets? Then let me not be counted a gentleman. If it please your ladyship I'll tell him you intend such a thing that he may prevent it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Dispute not my commands, but do them:
Or I shall stop the current of my favours.
That hitherto have flowed so fully on thee.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: Enter sir generous worthy, Jerker, Artlove, Y. Worthy, Susan, Jeffrey, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: I have brought you some guest's wife. Send your entertainment be worth their labour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I could wish it much better for master Jerker's sake.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: I fear you are too free that way.
I am yet a man, and my declining age
Hath not so weakened judgement in me,
That passion should betray my jealous thoughts.
Nor can I but suspect, and must be satisfied.
Her woman is the instrument. mrs. Susan.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: Pray sir, let me prepare her. No more will I
In the severer person of a counsellor
Instruct your care. But since by curious search
I have informed my knowledge
Even to satisfaction of his worth,
Let me commend this noble gentleman
Unto your best desires; let him possess them.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: Brother, without mature consideration
I dare not do an act; on which depends
Such dangerous events.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: My love's your warrant.
Have not I searched him thoroughly? have not I
Found him deserving all that's due to man,
Though malice were his judge. View but his person,
Art could not shape a more exact proportion:
And through his crystal bosom read his heart
Wherein such noble thoughts are charactered —

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: You shall command a poor gentleman any thing; neither do I expect reward. I only desire you will accept it as an act of my love. But why should you be jealous of my lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: Ask me no idle questions, but do it. Thou mayst be a lady thyself, if it lie in my power to raise thee.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Alas sir, an old man raise a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: We have a father (Brother) to whose care
We owe another duty, then that only
Which nature hath enjoined us for receiving
Our beings from him. Let not our rash wills
Swayed only by desire, run any course
Agrees not with his liking: yet I'll tell
The gentleman how much he owes your love
For thus commending him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: How now sir generous?
Courting my woman? am not I warm enough
To thaw your frozen appetite?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.l: Truly sir, if my lady knew how much I loved
You, 'twould make her jealous.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Indeed it would not.
Revenge should be a remedy.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: That's my fear.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Nay, to her again; you are not the first
That hath abused his lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: Wife, forgo these fond thoughts, and with care apply yourself to entertain these gentlemen. I'll to my closet.

div.stage: Goes forth.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I want but th' opportunity of their absence,
Which I must straight contrive.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: I am now animated
To come the nearest way without more circumstance;
And tell you how your beauty and your virtues
Have won on my desires to make them yours.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: I thank you sir, and could mine own eyes see
But half that worth my brother says is in you,
My equal thoughts should answer.

sp.speaker: Young ▪ W.
sp.p: What said she sir?

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: It seems you did commend me!

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: Yes by my hopes of good, no otherwise
Than I desire to have myself commended
Upon the like occasion.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.p: I must thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: I do interpret it; and have thought upon
Another trial. Let me entreat you sister
To construe my intentions right. Though I
Commended him, 'twas only to distinguish
Your passion and your reason. Now I find
The latter strongest, that you refuse the love
Of one so much defective.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: How! defective!
Brother, my judgement hath as searching eyes
Can see the fullness of his manly worth
Through all the vails of your detraction.
And now to show how much I do prefer
The freedom of my will before your counsel;
I'll tell him I do love him.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: Sister, I hope
You are not earnest!

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: As earnest as my love;
Which since I first beheld him took possession
Of all my thoughts, though customary niceness
Restrained me from discovering them; but now —

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Pray daughter oversee the servants.

div.stage: Exit Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.p: Mother beshrew your heart, she was in a good vein. But come sir, we'll pursue it.

div.stage: Exeunt young Worthy, and Artlove.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p:
It hath been no small punishment for me to
hold my peace all this while. My cousin is moral before company and counsel's my manners. But now I hope my tongue shall have liberty; and here's my lady's gentleman to exercise it with.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Your little cousin may stay. How like you the plot?

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: As the end proves it. And since your constancy
Hath held out 'gainst my lewd temptations,
Which have as well been trials of your virtues
As acts of wantonness, I here desist.
Henceforth my tongue shall never utter sound
Offensive to your modesty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pray let's sit,
And enter on the project, though it be nice
When wit masks virtue in a cloak of vice.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: They are going to it, and here's a little one will tell. Pray sir, can you keep counsel?

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: As well as a woman.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Indeed they and children are kin.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: You need not fear your secrets.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Then I shall love you heartily. But pray sir, no meddling with a gentleman's apron. Here's that will help your growth: please you to partake.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: She abuseth me, I must fit her. What is't mistress?

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Sack I assure you sir; and I hope you will love ● poor gentlewoman's as she loves you.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: If the butler be not too deeply interested.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Secretary.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You forget your employment.

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I saw your ladyship do nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do we not kiss!

sp.speaker: Susan.
sp.p: I run then, and dare not look back for fear of blushing.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: What strange contrivement's this?

div.head: The fourth scene.
div.stage: Enter sir generous worthy with Susan, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay, blush not Mr. jerker, ours is no act of shame, but to be gloried in; youth to youth. Sir generous are your horns so top-heavy they make you hang the head. Never droop at it man. A lord may be a cuckold and never the wiser: you have gotten the knowledge of what o● did but suspect before.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: Out of my warring thoughts discretion
Hath ordered a resolve, whose practice shall
Preserve my credit. Though I much wonder
A woman's smooth hypocrisy should make
Even her secretest actions to appear
Most virtuous; yet in this to stain her whiteness.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I did it sir to cure your jealousy
More than for satisfaction of desire,
Which I have often satiated, when
Your cold abilities were comforted
With down and silence; when your dreams presented
The quiet of a grave.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: I did it sir,
In gratitude for your hospitality.
Please you to take my counsel. Be divorced.
You need no proofs, since she's her own accuser.
I'll then procure a dispensation
And we'll be married.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis assented to.
Nay more, I'll give you all her portion back:
Nor shall the least disquiet in my thoughts
Make me remember it. Think not (Young man) mine age
so weak ▪ but I can conquer passion.
My act shall instantly have confirmation;
And be a precedent where such inequality
Of years are joined.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pray good sir generous stay.
I have not yet consented; and I think
The law cannot dispense whilst either live.
If you resolve divorce, you'll only force me
To an unwilling widowhood; and how little
My innocence deserves, the least suspect,
Though I did feign a guilt for better ends,
Just heaven can witness. There was no necessity
To tempt my woman to discover us.
It was my first command.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: I hear strange words
Which must be scanned and construed.

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.l: Here my solicits cease. But I desire
I may remain the servant of your virtues,
And wear your favours livery, whose example
Hath won on my resolves to reconcile
My wilder soul.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Whilst you persever in't,
I shall preserve you in my purest thoughts;
But never to infect them.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: The world reputes me
A man of full discretion; and mine age
Is not so rotten yet, to be twice child.
Hence ye vain jealousies, that in love diseased
Are peccant humours: therefore must be purged.
Come to my bosom pattern of true goodness.
Ne'er more those bugbears to the minds blessed quiet
Shall fright thee thence.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then will my joys be settled.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: Good sir forgive
The rashness of my passion. I'll no more
be jealous of your visits; but desire
The love I bear your person may be useful
To all good ends.

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: Enter Y. Worthy, Artlove, Dorothy, etc.

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: Nay, blush not sister;
Though it be virtue's colour. Say't again.
Here are more witnesses.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: Whence grows this exultation?

sp.speaker: Y. W.
sp.l: From in ward joy that she affects this gentleman,
Whose virtues won
Upon my love to be his orator;
And not respects infected with the mixture
Of any worse condition.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: Do you love him?

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: I hope to your kind judgement 'twill appear
A virtuous truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: If he be found deserving
In the dependences on blood and fortune
I shall consent, and then may mutual love
Render you happy.

sp.speaker: Artl.
sp.l: How am I blessed that your white soul
Hath bounded it's desires within the circuit
Of my too narrow worth!

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: Supper not ready yet ● my servants are musical; please you gentlemen to dance a little. 'tis a healthful exercise; bid them prepare their instruments. Come, come, settle to it.

div.stage: Spruce and Warrant, enter with music.

sp.l: I love to see a nimble activeness
In noble youth; it argues active minds
In well shaped bodies, and begets a joy
Dancing within me.

div.stage: Dance.

div.head: The sixth scene.
div.stage: Enter littleword, Tongall, dungworth, constable, Ralph and Dobson, by the middle Scene.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: Welcome neighbour Tongall: what mean these people?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I have brought them, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir gener.
sp.p: Whom, an't please you, master Constable.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: The thieves, an't please your worship, that robbed your worship's clerk.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Now warrant.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: How! I robbed! the constable is surely drunk. I was not robbed.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: How's that! did not you bring me to the tavern; show me the fellows, and direct me to apprehend them? Did you not promise me a share if they might be brought to a composition?

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Who? I? verily I say I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: How! not know the constable! Come Mr. warrant, let me understand the mystery without being farther abused. You forget the place where we had recreation for nothing, only promising the wench's favour upon occasion: against whom we afterwards informed to get fees.

sp.speaker: Sir gener.
sp.p: Is't no otherwise? it shall raise some mirth.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee Ralph, the gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p:
Well, 'tis a rare thing to be a justice. Were I but swelled with a little authority, methinks I could
cry, you rogue, you rascal, or you constable, most gravely.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: And 'tis as rare a thing to be a constable; to command in the name of authority, and be drunk at midnight, without danger of the stocks.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: I shall respect him mrs. Tongall. Mr. Constable I do conceive an abuse done to my person, in that you here traduce two strangers, pretending appointment, when none will accuse them; nor can I suddenly discover the error.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Now by all the painted authority of my staff —

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: No swearing constable; I have determined to confer a power upon the accused, to judge both it and you; and the most offenders shall suffer what shall be due.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Whither shall I fall! from my empire of command, to obey a mock-constable! The danger of example forbid it, that clowns and fool's be not made justices in earnest.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: No more of this modesty: I'll have it so; and exercise your wit. I have known a country fellow full of knavish clinches.

sp.speaker: Dobson.
sp.p: Yes sir, 'tis ordinary in a smith.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Then if I fit you not for a justice.

sp.speaker: Dobson.
sp.p: And I for a constable. You shall hear my tone.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: And I for an offendor.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Can you write and read young gentleman?

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Then you shall be my worship's clerk. And so I assume authority. (Hem, hem)

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: Now shall we be jeered out of our skins.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Set a good face on't.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: (Hem, hem,) what are you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: I am Dobson, the constable and't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: He lies and't please your worship, I am the constable.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: You were the constable; but your dignity is justly taken from you, and conferred upon honest John Dobson. Thou hast been a rascal sirrah, a corrupt constable. Thou hast conversed with deeds of darkness, hating the all light, but wenches and a lantern: which a married constable can never want at midnight. Thou hast watched little and prayed less: thou shalt therefore fast thyself into amendment. And so I commit thee with thy guard of billmen to the mercy of a Shrove-tuesdayes rebellion. (Hem, hem.)

sp.speaker: Dobson.
sp.p: Here's another defendant, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Now sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: A justice's clerk.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: O, I know you sirrah.
You write true Latin, not to be understood by the worshipful bench.

sp.speaker: Warr.
sp.p: Your worship is misinformed. I cannot write true orthography without a copy; and for Latin, I have less than the dean of Dunstable. I have read Ignoramus: but finding hard words which were not in the dictionary; I swear I understand it no more than Ignoramus himself.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Make his mittimus and send him to school; (Hem, hem,) what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: A gentleman usher.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p:
You are a malkin of mock-gentry; made up of silk and vainglory. You begin to grow out of fashion. I will therefore have you stitched into a case of compliments, and commended to some thrifty housekeeping lady in the country, where you may save her ladyship
the charge of a tailor; and if you can read, serve for a house-chaplain in rainy weather. (Hem, hem.) Bring that country gentleman before me.

sp.speaker: Dungworth
sp.p: You'll grow saucy sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sir Gene.
sp.p: Pray let's uphold the jest. I'll not spare mine own person. Your servant's witty.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: You are a country gentleman; a gallant out of fashion all the year; but especially at sessions, and upon high holidays, when your satin doublet draws away the eyes of the simple, and distracts their devotion almost into idolatry: giving it more worship than the heralds ever gave your ancestors. You intend as I understand to come forth in a new edition: and when the mercers and tailors have new printed you; and that some gentile wit may be read in your character to marry a wife in the city. You shall then have a pass sealed upon her by a courtier; be shipped at cuckold's haven, and so transported into Cornwall. (Hem, hem.) Now sir, what are you? never a wise word to answer a justice?

sp.speaker: Tong.
sp.p: He is my friend sir; and if you abuse him, you shall not have my daughter Jinny.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: There is a tempest in her tongue able to shake the foundation of the wisest justiceship.

sp.speaker: Dobs.
sp.p: My lady sir.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Madam, I have heard complaints of your ladyship, that you rise early every morning before noon, and are ready before night, unless there be a mask at court. You are likewise a great frequenter of the balls, merely out of charity to the poor fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: He hits you home wife.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: And this is my lady's gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Stop your ears gentlewomen, here's a foul business towards. But you may tell the man, the time and place, though not the manner.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Truly sir, if I am with child, 'tis but with a bottle of sack.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Give it me; I'll keep it. Many a justice in the city keeps children are none of his own. (Drinks.)

sp.speaker: Jerk.
sp.p: A right sack justice.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: And now for you gentlemen. You are of the wits that give poet's sack and old bevers, and vent their conceits in taverns for your own.

sp.speaker: Jeffr.
sp.p: Please you sir, these gentlemen are my friends.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: How's that! A justice take bribes! the example is too frequent, and I will have it mended.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: You begin now to overdo.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Bribes have purchased more than the whole race of aldermen since luds time.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.p: You are bitter now: 'tis time to resign.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: 'Tis time indeed, when I will not take bribes to be a justice quondam.

sp.speaker: Sir Gen.
sp.l: When wit makes not abuse it's exercise,
The users of it then are truly wise:
But 'tis a foolish vanity, not wit,
When conscience bounds are broke to practise it.

div.head: The epilogue.
div.l: You've seen a play, wherein was no disguise;
No wedding; no improbable device:
But all an easy matter, and contained
Within the time of action. 'tis arraigned;
And doubtful stands before your judgements bar,
Expecting what your several censures are.
Some that pretend commission to the stage,
As th'only Cato's of this critic age;
Condemning all not done by imitation,
Because this new play hath a new foundation
We fear will cry it down: our hope is then
That your fair hands will raise it up again.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
